organization.name: inblock.io assets GmbH
organization.description: Building trust infrastructure for sovereign data ownership through the Aqua Protocol, enabling decentralized notarization, verifiable data chains, and cryptographic data accounting.

protocol.name: Aqua Protocol
protocol.summary: An open-source, decentralized framework for secure verification of data assets through cryptographic proofs. Establishes data accountability and governance without requiring blockchain infrastructure. Only hashes are stored, preserving data confidentiality.
corePrinciples: Privacy-Preserving: Open-source protocol that doesn't require blockchain. Only cryptographic hashes are stored, maintaining data confidentiality.
Verifiable Data: Cryptographic hashes ensure tamper-proof records with portable verification that immediately detects any modifications.
Digital Sovereignty: Full control over your data. Independent data sharing and governance without third-party intermediaries.
capabilities: Upload and verify files with cloud-storage style notarization
Electronic signatures with portable verification trails
Self-sovereign identity with peer-to-peer attestation and challenge-based verification

current.summary: Cryptographic trust infrastructure addressing the AI security gap. Provides verifiable identity, granular access control, and tamper-proof provenance for AI systems operating at scale.

corePillars.name: Identity Crisis
corePillars.problem: AI agents act without verifiable identification. Spoofed identities and unauthorized delegation occur without accountability.
corePillars.solution: Self-sovereign identity with cryptographic attestation and peer-to-peer challenge-based verification.

corePillars.name: Access Chaos
corePillars.problem: No granular control over data consumption. Systems cannot audit what data was accessed, when, or by whom.
corePillars.solution: Revision-level permissions with auditable access trails and zero-trust architecture.

corePillars.name: Provenance Gap
corePillars.problem: Data origin remains unknown and tampering is undetectable.
corePillars.solution: Cryptographic hash chains for data integrity with portable verification independent of central authorities.

technicalArchitecture.name: Portable Hash-Chains
technicalArchitecture.description: AquaTrees are portable data structures recording revision history with cryptographic precision. Each change links via hash to its predecessor, preserving all versions.

technicalArchitecture.name: Modular Signatures
technicalArchitecture.description: Supports multiple signature schemes: Ethereum wallets, DIDs (Decentralized Identifiers), X.509 certificates, and others. Organizations plug in the cryptographic paradigm that fits their security requirements without changing the protocol.

technicalArchitecture.name: Immutable Timestamps
technicalArchitecture.description: Data anchors to tamper-proof timelines via Ethereum blockchain, qualified TSA services (eIDAS-compliant), or both. Blockchain is optional.

technicalArchitecture.name: Flexible Trust Models
technicalArchitecture.description: Bridges institutional and decentralized worlds. Supports enterprise registries for compliance and community-driven decentralized registries for open verification.

regulatoryAlignment.relevance: AI accountability framework recommending investment in provenance technologies, standard disclosures for architecture/data/performance, and independent evaluations of high-risk systems.
Mandates data governance with provenance documentation, automatic logging for traceability, and transparency obligations. Non-compliance penalties up to 7% of global turnover.

stable.summary: Production-ready protocol version powering the AquaFire Application and Aqua JS SDK.

products.name: AquaFire Application
products.description: Official reference implementation of the Aqua Protocol. A Document Management System with integrated identity verification, document e-signing, and portable verification trails.

products.name: Aqua JS SDK
products.description: Developer tools for building applications with the Aqua Protocol. TypeScript implementation enabling integration of verifiable data chains into existing systems.

pinned.name: aquafier-js
pinned.description: Reference implementation of the AquaFire Application, the Aqua Protocol-powered Document Management System with identity verification and e-signing.

pinned.name: aqua-js-sdk
pinned.description: Implementation of Aqua Protocol v3.2. Developer SDK for building Aqua-enabled applications.

pinned.name: aqua-docs
pinned.description: Aqua Documentation including the protocol specification.

pinned.name: aqua-js-cli
pinned.description: JavaScript CLI client for the Aqua external verifier.

pinned.name: DataSymmetry
pinned.description: Data symmetry tooling for balanced data governance.

team.name: Tim Bansemer
team.summary: ICT Systems Engineer with over a decade of expertise in IT infrastructure, security, and distributed networks. Pioneered the Aqua Protocol since 2021, driving innovations in digital sovereignty, data provenance, and cryptographic proofs for verifiable data accounting.

team.name: Publius Dirac
team.summary: Core contributor to the Aqua Protocol since 2021 with expertise in free and open-source software, decentralization, and quantum computing. Focuses on research, prototyping, and post-quantum cryptography.

glossary.definition: A portable data structure recording revision history with cryptographic precision, where each change links via hash to its predecessor.
Applying rigorous accounting standards to data through cryptographic verification, ensuring provenance, integrity, and authenticity.
Full control over one's own data through self-hosted, open-source trust infrastructure without dependency on external platforms.
A cryptographic chain of hashes forming an immutable revision history that can be independently verified without a central authority.
On-premises document notarization providing secure, verifiable proof of document integrity and signing without third-party involvement.
A pluggable signature system supporting Ethereum wallets, DIDs, X.509 certificates, and other cryptographic schemes within the same protocol.

Cryptographic proof that a training document was created by a specific author under a declared license. Without it, AI companies cannot demonstrate artifact-by-artifact that content was appropriately licensed — the root cause of ongoing AI copyright litigation.

The guarantee that documents retrieved into an AI model's context window are authentic and unmodified. Without signed retrieved chunks, the context window is an open injection surface for indirect prompt injection attacks.

A cryptographically verifiable chain linking a consequential AI agent action back to the human who authorized it, preserving scope attenuation at each delegation hop (each sub-agent can only reduce scope, never expand it). OAuth tokens prove authentication but do not prove scope was preserved through delegation.

A tamper-evident record binding a model's output to the model that produced it. Without it, there is no way to verify that what a user sees — after post-processors, safety filters, UI layers, and caches — is what the model actually produced.

The degradation of AI training data quality as future models increasingly train on prior AI-generated web content rather than human-created content. Cryptographic provenance (signatures from verified human-controlled keys) enables verifiable filtering of training sets; probabilistic AI-content detectors do not.

An attack where a malicious actor controls a document that ends up in an AI model's retrieval set, embedding instructions the model then executes. Becomes more dangerous as AI agents take consequential actions. Signed retrieved content with policy enforcement before context injection is a structural defence.
